Your Rights Attending a Protest

  • You have the right to speak out on public property. However, you must not interfere with the purpose in which these properties were built for.
  • You have the right to photograph anything within the public space including the police. If you see and hear acts of violence or police brutality, don’t be afraid to take pictures or record them. Also, remember the officer’s badge, patrol car number, and agency.
    • You’re able to write a complaint with the agency’s internal affairs division or file a civilian complaint with evidence of abuse.
    • Without an issued warrant, police officers can’t confiscate or demand to see your phone. However, they may order bystanders to stop activities that are truly interfering with law enforcement operations.
    • Under some states, recording audio of a police officer may be illegal. Do a quick google search prior!
  • Police officers may redirect you to move to the side of a street or a sidewalk or may disperse a crowd if there are clear and dangerous signs of disorder, traffic interference, and threat to public safety.

Your Rights Interacting With State Police Officers

  • During an arrest, ask the office what crime you’re suspected of committing. Ask witnesses to record the arrest and clearly identify yourself: Your name, date of birth, and an emergency number to call. This information could be written on the wrist of your arm.
  • During an arrest, try to get witness information. Ask for their name, date of birth, and contact information–whether that be a phone number or an email address. Also, try to get information on the officer(s) at the scene: their badge(s), patrol car number(s), and agency.
  • During an arrest, you have the right to remain silent and the right to request for a lawyer. It’s best to remain silent and deny requests to sign papers without a lawyer. Anything could be used in favor or against your favor in this open case.
  • During your arrest, you have the right to make a local phone call. They may not listen to the conversation if you’ve chosen to dial your lawyer.
  • If you’re not suspected of carrying a weapon, the police may not search you nor your belongings without your consent.
